entry.title: SAP CPI Dynamic Router with External Rule Set using Camel Simple Expressions
entry.content:
Intro

Routing in CPI can get messy. As more routing branches are added, maintaining them becomes a headache, especially when conditions get complex or frequently change.

 

Background / Problem

I've explored a few ways to reduce this pain.

One is convention-based processDirect routing, e.g. building endpoint dynamically from headers like: /PD_${header.mestyp}_${header.rcvprn}. It‚Äôs simple and router-free, but can‚Äôt handle complex routing conditions.

Another is using value mapping for routing, lookup a field to get the processDirect path. See link at [Ref 1] & [Ref 2]. But VM has serious limits:

  • Only supports single field matching
  • No clean way to do AND logic without messy field concatenation
  • Can‚Äôt return multiple matching rows
  • No support for rich conditions like contains, startsWith, greaterThan, etc.

If you try to simulate those rich conditions in VM, it gets hacky, need to embed pseudo-logic in values, then decode with Groovy. That‚Äôs fragile and hard to maintain.

You could build your own rule engine, but that becomes a long-term maintenance trap. You‚Äôll keep adding custom operators, fixing your own rule evaluation engine, and it won‚Äôt be standard. I wouldn‚Äôt go that route.

 

Inspiration

While revisiting the Dynamic Router pattern from Gregor Hohpe‚Äôs EIP book and Apache Camel, I realized: CPI should be able to support dynamic, flexible routing, if the conditions are externalized and evaluated at runtime.

The core idea of a true Dynamic Router:

  • Rules are externally maintained
  • Easy to add/remove/update
  • Supports rich conditions (not just equals)
  • Still simple to implement

Camel is the backbone of CPI, so I turned to Camel‚Äôs Simple Expression language.

 

Research

After revisit a great blog [Ref 3] by Eng Swee, found out able to use evaluate() method to get value using Groovy, however, it doesn't return single true or false.

Until at [Ref 4] Camel SimpleBuilder JavaDoc, found the method: matches()

 

Discovery

With SimpleBuilder.matches(), I can evaluate conditions like below with headers/properties in Groovy to Boolean true/false. Please note that for matches() method, Both ("and", "or") is not working, have to use actual operator (&&, II). Need double equal sign. Below 2 examples:

${header.type} == 'SO' && ${header.class} == 'A'
${header.partNumber.startsWith('FG')}

This opened up new possibilities and a clean path: I can store rules as just two fields:

  • endpoint (processDirect path)
  • condition (simple expression)

Evaluate them in Groovy using matches(). If it returns true, route to that endpoint.

 

How it work: Dynamic Simple Expression matches()

You can build "Simple Expression Tester" to test simple expression from Postman.

Step 1: Build an iFlow like below. Allowed Header(s) must be *

 

Step 2: Add the script testSimpleExpression.groovy that do evaluate() and matches() on some Simple Expression:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import org.apache.camel.Exchange
import org.apache.camel.builder.SimpleBuilder

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def headers = message.getHeaders()
  
    Exchange ex = message.exchange

    def evaluateSimple = { simpleExpression ->
        SimpleBuilder.simple(simpleExpression).evaluate(ex, String)
    }

    def matchSimple = { simpleExpression ->
        SimpleBuilder.simple(simpleExpression).matches(ex)
    }

    def condition = evaluateSimple('${header.condition}')
    def result = matchSimple(condition)

    def output = "condition: " + condition + "\r\n" + "result: " + result
    message.setBody(output)

    return message
}

Step 3: Positive Test Run. Header class & type matched the condition, result = true

Step 4: Negative Test Run. Changed class from A to B, then result = false

Step 5: Tried with some other method like startsWith() still work. I not tried all possible method, however believe as long as the method work in Camel Simple Expression, will work in this iFlow too.

 

Dynamic Router with External Rule Set (Simple Expression)

After testing and a few iterations, this worked well. So now ready to build a mini rule engine that is simple, dynamic, and avoids all the earlier pain points.

Step 1: Below will be our rule set in JSON, telling the processDirect endpoint and condition. The name field is just as an identifier for the rule.

[
    {
        "name": "ReceiverA",
        "endpoint": "/PD_SO_A",
        "condition": "${header.type} == 'SO' && ${header.class} == 'A'"
    },
    {
        "name": "ReceiverB",
        "endpoint": "/PD_PO_B",
        "condition": "${header.type} == 'PO' && ${header.class} == 'B'"
    }
]

Step 2: Build below 'Dynamic Router' iflow. For demo purpose, the sender is HTTP adapter. In actual you may change to processDirect. Allowed Header(s) must be *

Step 3: That "getPDSimpleRule" script, for now you can just use content modifier set static JSON rule set to property "simpleRule". We going to change to Partner Directory later.

Step 4: Script "doDynamicRouting". This script loop each rule, if condition matched, set the endpoint in property, also do logging in custom headers for traceability.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper
import org.apache.camel.Exchange
import org.apache.camel.builder.SimpleBuilder

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)
    def properties = message.getProperties()

    Exchange ex = message.exchange
    def matchSimple = { simpleExpression ->
        SimpleBuilder.simple(simpleExpression).matches(ex)
    }
    def simpleRule = message.getProperty("simpleRule")
    def simpleRuleJSON = new JsonSlurper().parseText(simpleRule)

    properties.put("endpoint", "/not_found_from_rule")

    for(rule in simpleRuleJSON){
        def name = rule.name ?: ""
        def endpoint = rule.endpoint ?: ""
        def condition = rule.condition ?: ""

        def result = matchSimple(condition)

        if(result == true){
            messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("name", name)
            messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("condition", condition)
            messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("endpoint", endpoint)

            properties.put("endpoint", endpoint)
            break
        }
    }

    return message
}
 
Step 5: For demo, build 2 different receivers with processDirect. Each with sender address: /PD_SO_A and /PD_PO_B.

 

Positive Test Run (Go to ReceiverA)


 

Positive Test Run (Go to ReceiverB)

 

Negative Test Run (When no rule matches)

 

Where To Store The Rule Set?

One possible way is to store Json rule set in Partner Directory. SAP CPI do have UI to upload JSON to Partner Directory. Below are steps to upload JSON to Partner Directory:

Step 1: At CPI Monitor, go to 'Partner Directory'

Step 2: Click '+' to add:

Step 3: Maintain like below, browse to JSON rule set file, then 'Create'.

Step 4: After maintain, you should see like below:

Step 5: Replace the step 'getPDSimpleRule' with below script. This script get simpleRule JSON from Partner Directory.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import com.sap.it.api.pd.PartnerDirectoryService
import com.sap.it.api.ITApiFactory
import com.sap.it.api.pd.BinaryData

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def service = ITApiFactory.getApi(PartnerDirectoryService.class, null);
    if(service == null){
        throw new IllegalStateException("Partner Directory Service not found");
    }

    def simpleRuleData = service.getParameter("SimpleRule", "DynamicRouter" , BinaryData.class)
    def simpleRule = new String(simpleRuleData.getData())

    message.setProperty("simpleRule", simpleRule)

    return message
}

Step 6: If future need to maintain the JSON rule set, come here, Edit..

then just Browse and upload updated JSON rule file. Filename doesn't matter, Partner Directory will auto rename.

 

Closing Summary

This approach doesn‚Äôt aim to replace complex rule engines, but for many real-world routing needs, it strikes the right balance: flexible, simple, and maintainable. If you‚Äôve struggled with hardcoded routers or limited value mappings in CPI, this might be a cleaner path forward.

What do you think about this approach?

If you‚Äôve tackled similar routing challenges in CPI, I‚Äôd be curious how you approached it. Feel free to share your thoughts, improvements, or alternative ideas.

Disclaimer: This is a pattern I sparked from EIP pattern(Dynamic Router) and made workable in CPI, but it hasn‚Äôt been used in real production environments yet. Use it at your own discretion.

 

References:

[Ref 1] IDOC Dispatching - Use case for the ProcessDirect Adapter from @ArielBravo

[Ref 2] SAP Cloud Integration IDoc Receiver Handler from @aayushaggarwal

[Ref 3] Using Camel's Simple in CPI Groovy scripts from @engswee

[Ref 4] Class SimpleBuilder JavaDoc from Apache Camel

[Ref 5] EIPinCPI - Dynamic Router & EIPinCPI - Message Dispatcher  from @bhalchandraswcg

[Ref 6] Get to know Camel‚Äôs Simple expression language in SAP Cloud Integration from @MortenWittrock

[Ref 7] DynamicRouter EIP from Enterprise Integration Patterns (https://www.enterpriseintegrationpatterns.com/)

entry.title: Optimized IDoc Routing in SAP CI with Value Mapping and Groovy-Based Receiver Determination
entry.content:
Target Audience

This blog is primarily intended for the SAP Integration community seeking a strategy for routing outbound IDoc flows from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems‚Äîparticularly for those migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Cloud Integration (Formerly known as SAP Cloud Platform Integration or SAP CPI) and exploring effective alternatives to implement the same.

Motivation

In traditional SAP PI/PO-based landscapes, routing outbound IDocs from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems is straightforward. A single t-RFC destination and IDoc port are typically configured in the sender system to forward all IDocs to SAP PI. Within SAP PI, routing is managed efficiently using the Integration Directory and centralized runtime (AEX), enabling reuse of a single IDoc destination across multiple interfaces and message types (MATMAS, INVOIC, DEBMAS, etc).

However, when migrating to SAP Cloud Integration, this simplicity is disrupted. Cloud Integration does not provide an equivalent mechanism for managing IDoc traffic using a central gateway or common destination. Instead, each interface often requires its own unique endpoint, destination, and port, making the configuration effort redundant and makes IDoc Routing complex  and operationally challenging, as part of this blog I wanted to tackle these challenges and simplify this. (* I wont go into the specific challenges of the different approches and rather focus on the problems I am trying to solve in the current approach)

 

Solution Approach:

As described in the flow above, we will implement the design using two iFlows:

  • IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting:
    This iFlow receives IDoc XML messages from various SAP systems. It is responsible for receiver determination and routes the message to the appropriate target iFlow based on routing logic.
    In SAP PI/PO terminology, this iFlow handles the Inbound Processing and Receiver Determination steps of the integration pipeline.

  • IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>:
    This iFlow is specific to the receiver system and handles transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.
    In SAP PI/PO terms, this iFlow corresponds to the Interface Determination and Outbound Processing steps of the integration pipeline.

IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting

Step 1: Extract Details from EDI_DC40 of IDoc xml and create Exchange properties: 

The IDoc routing in this flow primarily relies on Value Mappings and Groovy scripts. In this step, the necessary inputs and variables are initialized‚Äîthese are later used in Groovy script execution to extract routing details from the configured Value Mappings.

For example, consider a sender system Q10 (the quality environment of the x10 SAP system with client number 001) sending an INVOIC IDoc with an extension type ZINVOIC01. The properties are initialized as below.

                                    

The sentReceiverCount variable is initialized to zero and is later used during processing when the same IDoc meets conditions for multiple receivers, ensuring it is sent to each applicable receiver accordingly.

Step 2: Fetch Receiver List for the IDOC from the Value Mapping tables using Exchange properties:

For this we would need to maintain two value mappings

Value Mapping for Sender Partner Number to Sender Identifier Conversion:

As an example, I have maintained the details of SAP systems x10 and x20 across their Development, Quality, and Production environments. You would similarly maintain all relevant SAP systems and their corresponding identifiers in the Value Mapping used for IDoc routing. This mapping typically requires updates only when new SAP systems are added or existing systems are migrated (when SIDs change), which are relatively infrequent events.

Value Mapping for ReceiverList, Receiver Determination and Receiver Target IFlow URls:

The second Value Mapping is maintained for each unique combination of SAP sender system and IDoc type.
For example, to define receiver determination conditions for the IDOC: INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 sent from the SAP system x10, you would create a corresponding Value Mapping entry as shown below.

The ValueMapping will have 3 Mapping with agency as x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 (sender Identifier.IDOC)

IDOCName to ReceiverList : This mapping holds a list of all receivers applicable for a specific IDoc.

ReceiverName to ReceiverCondition: This defines the receiver determination condition for each receiver. The conditions should be maintained using XPath expressions to evaluate the IDoc content dynamically.

ReceiverName to ReceiverIFlowAddress: This maps each receiver to the endpoint URL of its corresponding integration flow (IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>) , as described earlier in the solution approach.

Now that we've covered how the Value Mappings are maintained, let‚Äôs look at how the Groovy script fetches the appropriate values:

1. Fetch senderIdentifier
The senderIdentifier is retrieved using the exchange property senderPartnerNumber (set in step 1). This value is looked up from the first ValueMapping.
Example:
If a message is sent from system Q10 with sender partner number Q10_001, the senderIdentifier fetched from the Value Mapping would be x10.

2. Construct Agency Key
Using the senderIdentifier and other exchange properties (set in step 1), the agency key is constructed. This key will be used to retrieve routing information from the second ValueMapping.
Agency Format:
<senderIdentifier>.<messageType>.<IDocType>[.<extensionType>]
     senderIdentifier ‚Äì from first Value Mapping
     messageType ‚Äì from exchange property
     IDocType ‚Äì from exchange property
     extensionType ‚Äì from exchange property (optional)
Example:
For an INVOIC IDoc of type INVOIC01 with extension ZINVOIC01 sent from system x10, the agency would be: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01

3. Fetch Receiver List
Using the constructed agency key, the receiver list is retrieved from the second ValueMapping.
Example:
For the agency x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01, the receiver list will be:
Receiver1, Receiver2, Receiver3
Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverList')

Step3: Execute Receiver Determination Conditions (Groovy Script) from Value Mapping

The Groovy script then iterates through the receiver list, fetching the corresponding receiver determination condition for each receiver and evaluating it against the IDoc content using XPath.

// Fetch condition from Value Mapping
currentReceiverCondition = valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverName',
  'Receiver1',
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverCondition'
)
// Evaluate condition
def expr = xpath.compile(currentReceiverCondition as String)
def result = expr.evaluate(doc, XPathConstants.BOOLEAN)

If the condition evaluates to true, the receiver is added to the exchange property determinedReceivers. A counter variable determinedReceiverCount is also maintained to track how many receivers matched successfully.

At the end of this step, three additional exchange properties will be available: determinedReceivers, determinedReceiverCount, and IDOCName (which holds the constructed agency key).

In the example discussed, lets consider if the conditions are satisfied for Receiver2 and Receiver3, then the determinedReceivers list will contain both, and the determinedReceiverCount will be set to 2.
The IDOCName property (i.e., the agency key: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01) is also stored to be reused in subsequent steps of the flow.

Step 4: Send Message to Receiver Specific flow for the  Determined Receivers 

In this step, a looping process call is executed, which repeatedly invokes a local integration process to send the message to each receiver identified in the previous step‚Äîone at a time.

The property sentReceiverCount is incremented after each message is successfully sent to a determined receiver. The loop continues until sentReceiverCount equals determinedReceiverCount, at which point the process terminates.

To send the message to a specific receiver, a Groovy script is used to retrieve the receiver name from the determinedReceivers list. Using this name, the script fetches the endpoint URL of the corresponding receiver-specific iFlow from the second ValueMapping.

Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverIFlowAddress'
)

The fetched endpoint URL is then assigned to the header property receiverProcessDirectURL, which is used by the ProcessDirect adapter to route the message to the appropriate receiver-specific iFlow. IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description> which would handle  transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.

 

Advantages of the Proposed IDoc Routing Strategy in SAP Cloud Integration

 The strategy outlined in this blog offers a scalable, modular, and maintainable alternative that aligns closely with enterprise integration requirements. Below are the key advantages of this design:

1. Reusability of Integration Flows

Instead of creating a separate iFlow for each IDoc-to-receiver combination, this approach separates:
Generic routing logic (IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting)
Receiver-specific logic(IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface>)
Benefit: Reduces development effort and avoids duplication across iFlows, enabling a clean and modular architecture.

2. Centralized Routing with Value Mappings

Routing conditions and receiver lists are managed through Value Mapping artifacts.
Benefit: Updates to routing logic can be done without modifying or redeploying iFlows‚Äîjust update the Value Mapping configuration.

3. Scalable Across Systems and IDoc Variants

Routing logic is built dynamically using:
- Sender system identifier
- Message type
- IDoc type
- (Optional) Extension type
Benefit: Supports complex multi-system, multi-IDoc scenarios without inflating the number of artifacts or flows.

4. Native Support for Multi-Receiver Scenarios

The use of Groovy logic and looping constructs enables routing to multiple receivers based on evaluated XPath conditions.
Benefit: Enables 1:n routing scenarios, ensuring the same IDoc can be routed to multiple receivers without message duplication logic.

5. Low Maintenance and High Adaptability

This architecture requires Value Mapping updates only when:
- New SAP systems are added
- Existing systems are migrated
- Additional receiver conditions are introduced
Benefit: Minimal maintenance effort over time; no need for frequent design or deployment changes.

6. Aligned with SAP PI/PO Routing Model

The flow structure mirrors familiar SAP PI/PO pipeline steps, such as:
- Receiver Determination
- Interface Determination
- Outbound Processing
Benefit: Simplifies migration for teams transitioning from SAP PI/PO to SAP CI, while preserving key routing concepts. Also there is a scope for automation where you could write a code to automate creation of Valuemapping. The existing  ports can be reused by updating the RFC destination pointing to the SAP CI 

This approach attempts to addresses the Technical limitations of SAP CI‚Äôs IDoc handling, and also supports sustainable growth and cleaner and maintainable integration landscapes.

Additional Considerations for Retry and Reprocessing

  1. Retry and error handling should be implemented within each receiver-specific flow to manage failures independently for every receiver.

  2. It is advisable to avoid broadcasting IDocs directly from SAP Cloud Integration, especially in high-volume scenarios like master data distribution across multiple systems. This is due to potential limitations in storing failed messages within the SAP Cloud Integration tenant. Additionally, in broadcast cases, the retry mechanism should support resending only to the receivers where failures occurred, not all recipients.

  3. Exceptions can be returned to the sender system (e.g., via SOAP fault) so that errors are reflected in the originating SAP system(Return Exception to Sender ). This enables visibility in transaction logs like WE02/WE05, helping to identify and reprocess failed IDocs more effectively.

  4. Batch jobs in the SAP backend responsible for reprocessing IDocs should be adjusted based on the new failure status codes introduces by this setup

 

Conclusion

This blog attempted to present a scalable, maintainable, modular and  operationally efficient strategy for receiver determination of outbound IDocs from SAP system by leveraging Groovy script and Value Mapping. Also by decoupling the routing and receiver-specific logic into two separate iFlows, the solution ensures better reusability, easier maintenance, and greater control over message processing.

entry.title: AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
The AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite is a Generative AI driven capability available exclusively on SAP Integration Suite. For the first time in SAP CI, leverage SAP AI Core‚Äôs GenAI Hub features that allow you to achieve smarter integration solutions for your business.

AICore-GenAIHub variant allows you to connect to orchestration services in SAP AI Core. This service enables the use of various generative AI models with a unified code, configuration, and deployment.

The Custom-OpenAI-REST variant of the AI adapter works with the APIs of OpenAI that allows developers to access and integrate with artificial intelligence models into their applications, enabling tasks like text generation, image creation, and more.

AI Adapter Features

The AI Adapter has the following features:

  • AI Adapter has two variants available: AICore-GenAIHub and Custom-OpenAI-REST.
  • AI Adapter supports OAuth2 Client Credential (User Credentials) and API Key alias (Secure Parameter) authentication methods for the AICore-GenAIHub and Custom-OpenAI-REST variant respectively.
  • AICore-GenAIHub employs harmonized API to allow you to use different foundation models without changing the client code.
  • You can configure orchestration to enable consumption of multiple GenAI models within a single workflow.

  4. Select Back-end Type as Non-SAP System and click Next.

entry.title: New integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration
entry.content:
I would like to share with you an important change for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration that we did based on feedback we received from customers running the Pipeline. As a result, new integration packages for supporting the Pipeline for Cloud Integration has been recently shipped on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Those packages replace the so far provided package Process Integration Pipeline - Generic Integration Flows & Templates which will be deprecated soon.

To be more flexible in setting up your different pipelines, different sender-specific IDoc and XI inbound flows, and receiver-specific outbound flows if required, we decided to split up the Process Integration Pipeline - Generic Integration Flows & Templates into four packages. For the same reason, the script collection has been replaced by local scripts.

Customers like to run different pipelines, e.g., for distributing their critical and non-critical scenarios across different pipelines, or setting up different pipelines in a shared tenant environment. Also, it makes sense to define an own IDoc or XI inbound flow for each sender system to be able for instance to define a sender-specific user role or to stop incoming messages for a specific sender system. For those uses cases, so far you had to copy the package with the complete number of integration flows from the Discovery to the Design adding a suffix. This ensured that the copied packages were not cut off from future updates. However, downside was that this resulted in a large number of stale artifacts, so integration flows which were not used at all.

With the new package setup, we now better support those use cases without creating all those stale integration artifacts. The approach is still to copy a new package from the Discovery, but depending on the use case, you would only copy the integration flows which are required for the respective use case.

You can now find the generic integration flows and a set of templates for the scenario-specific integration flows and custom exits spread across the following integration packages:

  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Inbound: Contains the generic IDoc and XI inbound flows.
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Pipelines: Contains the main generic pipeline steps.
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound: Contains the generic outbound processing flow.
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Templates: Contains all templates for the scenario-specific flows and custom extensions.

Note: As said, the so far provided integration package will be deprecated soon. All new feature increments will only be shipped with the new integration packages. So, If you have used the previously provided package, you need to switch to the new packages. To do so, proceed as follows:

  • Undeploy all generic flows from the soon to be deprecated package.
  • Configure and deploy the required generic flows provided by the new Cloud Integration Pipeline packages. You can either deploy all generic flows or just the ones that you need depending on which pipeline you use, see below.
  • If you have used scripts from the script collection in your scenario-specific flows, replace the scripts with local scripts. You find the local scripts in either the generic flows or the new templates. As long as you haven't replaced all scripts, recommendation is to still run the script collection. Once done, you can then also undeploy the script collection.

Note: In the newly shipped Cloud Integration packages, the name and IDs of the integration flows have version v2 added. It's important that the old integration flows and the new integration flows must not be deployed together because they compete on reading from the same JMS queues.

The templates package doesn't contain any artifact which needs to be deployed nor does it need to be transported to the production tenant. It only contains templates that you can copy to create your scenario-specific flows and custom flows. For this reason, we kept those integration flows in a separate package.

For setting up the integrated messaging runtime for asynchronous communication (recommended option for asynchronous communication), you need to deploy the following generic integration flows:

  • (Optionally, if you like to use a single entry point for IDoc messages) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for Idoc
  • (Optionally, if you like to use a single entry point for XI messages) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for XI
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Async
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing

For setting up the integrated messaging runtime for synchronous content-based-router scenarios, you need to deploy the following generic integration flows:

  • (Optionally) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for XI
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Sync

For setting up the fully decoupled pipeline for asynchronous communication, you need to deploy the following integration flows:

  • (Optionally) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for Idoc
  • (Optionally) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for XI
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Inbound Processing
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step04 - Receiver Determination
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step05 - Interface Determination
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing

All integration flows within the new Cloud Integration packages have been copied from the old package. Besides this, some new features have been added which I will soon describe in a bit more detail in a separate blog post. You also find this information in the change logs of the packages. Upfront, here some of the new features that we have shipped with the new packages:

  • For IDoc inbound scenarios where you exchange IDoc bulk messages, you have the option to keep the bulk, i.e., not to split the bulk message into individual messages.
  • You can now call a custom exit integration flow for custom pre-processing without the need to alter the standard generic flows of the pipeline. This can be configured globally or scenario-specific. Potential use cases could be to implement additional external or internal logging capabilities or to stop certain messages from sending to the receiver systems based on some conditions, e.g. maintained in the Partner Directory.
  • A new template has been added that allows you to implement custom receiver and interface determination by maintaining exchange properties. A similar approach is applied in the SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration migration tool when selecting the standard migration approach for the Recipient List and Content-Based-Router patterns.
  • A new template has been added for an option to implement custom receiver determination based on a message mapping and by maintaining exchange properties for the interface determination. A similar approach is applied in the SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration migration tool when selecting the Pipeline migration approach.
  • For the Outbound Processing templates, an option to call custom post-processing has been added.
  • We fixed an issue in the duplication check caused by a wrong usage of the escalation end event for the IDoc and XI inbound processing flow.

We are currently updating the standard documentation, so stay tuned.

entry.title: SAP RISE - Six Integration Patterns You‚Äôll Face
entry.content:
In one of my previous blogs Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters ‚Äì A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration I have given some insights in which projects & situations I am currently using ISA-M to define my Integration patterns.  What should be more strategic then RISE nowadays?  

 

üß≠ The Integration Architect‚Äôs Dilemma in RISE Projects

It usually starts with excitement ‚Äî ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre moving to RISE!‚Äù. But as the Integration Architect, you feel a shift in the room once you ask:

‚ÄúHow will your business-critical integrations survive the move?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow will our Integration Patterns change in a Private Cloud Environment?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo we have to an option to be part of this modernization?‚Äù

In too many RISE conversations, integration is not part of initial phases , but everything depends on it. Whether you‚Äôre facing direct system-to-system integrations, legacy SAP PO platforms, or the modernization path toward Integration Suite and AEM: you need clarity.

 

Let‚Äôs talk about the 6 most common integration scenarios I encounter in RISE projects ‚Äî and let‚Äôs do a deep dive into one of them.

üìåContext: What Makes RISE Integration Different?

ISA-M allows us to talk in Integration patterns ‚Äî proven, repeatable ways to connect cloud, on-prem, and hybrid landscapes.

Draw your Integration landscape abstract as below and repeat the same for all Integration Domains and Integration Patterns, maybe Integration Styles. We focus on the common Process Integration patterns which often are.

üîç Scenario 1: On-Premise to On-Premise (e.g., existing ECC system ‚Üí S/4, within same on-prem datacenter)

üí¨ Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their systems locally. No RISE adaption in this case

üîç Scenario 2: Private Cloud to Private Cloud (e.g., S/4 to S/4 Integration, within same RISE datacenter)

 

üîßTechnology in use:

  • SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on a Private Cloud hyperscaler, such as Azure or AWS 
  • VPN or direct peering within same hyperscaler
  • Azure VNet Peering, AWS VPC Peering, or similar as secure tunnel
  • *SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on On-Premise landscape ( e.g. on SUSE or Red Hat) is also a valid option

Differentiators

  • Usage of Application Interface Framework for S/4HANA Monitoring
  • Usage of transactions and APIM Management operations
  • Usage of SAP CALM for overall central Monitoring ( if applicable)

üîç Scenario 3: Private Cloud to Public Cloud (RISE workload connects to SaaS like SuccessFactors)

üí¨ Comment:

For hybrid Integration SAP Integration Suite could be used as natural entry point

üîç Scenario 4: Public Cloud to Public Cloud (e.g., SuccessFactors ‚Üî Ariba or Salesforce ‚Üî S/4 in RISE)

üí¨ Comment:
This is a modernization sweet spot. Cloud-native to cloud-native with no concrete RISE touchpoints.

üîç Scenario 5: On-Premise to Public Cloud

üí¨ Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their backend systems locally but use SaaS applications for certain LoBs. No RISE adaption in this case

üîç Scenario 6: On-Premise to Private Cloud (e.g., ECC ‚Üí RISE in Azure, hybrid operation)

üí¨ Comment:
This hybrid pattern is very common in staged RISE transitions. Customers keep some systems on-prem while moving others (‚Äúearly adaptors) into RISE.

 

üîßModernization Reality Check

Most customers do one of three things:

  1. Move PO Interfaces to SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration  and SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell  
  2. Modernize to SAP Advanced Event Mesh
  3. Use more featreus of the SAP Integration Suite, such as API Managmenet

So here‚Äôs what I recommend to every architect:

  • Audit your interface and integration technologies before RISE.
  • Classify interfaces using along the patterns in this blog.
  • Decide per pattern: Keep, Modernize, or Sunset.
  • Actively design your new integration landscape ‚Äî don‚Äôt wait for someone else to.

 

üìû Let‚Äôs Build Smarter RISE Integrations

I‚Äôve worked on numerous RISE integration journeys and built a reference architecture library covering each scenario. If you want to see the diagrams, dig into patterns, or compare your setup ‚Äî I‚Äôm happy to help.

Ping us on SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: Invoking LLM from Cloud Integration Responsibly ‚Äì Made Easy with Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core
entry.content:
In this blog post, I‚Äôll walk you through how to seamlessly invoke large language models (LLMs) from Cloud Integration using the Generative AI Hub and the Orchestration Workflow API in SAP AI Core. We‚Äôll focus on building a GDPR-compliant automation flow that leverages data masking and pseudonymisation to ensure privacy while still delivering value from generative AI.

The scenario we'll explore simulates a real-world use case: when a Business Partner record is updated in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, a personalized email notification is generated by an LLM and automatically sent out via Cloud Integration.

Thanks to prebuilt orchestration capabilities of Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core, such as templating, I/O filtering, and data masking, the process of generating compliant LLM responses can be achieved with just a single API call.

‚ÄÉ

Before diving into the implementation steps, let‚Äôs take a closer look at the process flow behind this sample scenario.

Process Flow (Steps)

  1. Business Partner Update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
    A user creates or edits a Business Partner record in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
  2. Event Triggered and Message Sent to SAP AEM
    The system triggers an event and sends a message to SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM).
  3. Cloud Integration iFlow Subscribes and Starts Processing
    The CPI iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and begins processing as soon as a new message is published.
  4. Retrieve Old Payload from CAP Application
    The iFlow queries the CAP application to retrieve the previous version (old payload) of the Business Partner record from SAP HANA Cloud.
  5. Call the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core for AI-Based Email Generation
    With both the old and new payloads in hand, the iFlow invokes the Generative AI Hub using the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core to generate a personalized email body in HTML format. Here, a predefined orchestration pipeline applies data masking, prompt templating, and foundation model invocation to generate a compliant, personalised email body ‚Äì without exposing any sensitive data.
  6. Send Email to Business Partner
    The iFlow sends the generated email to the Business Partner‚Äôs email address via a standard mail adapter in Cloud Integration, completing the end-to-end notification process.

As part of this blog, I will not focus on connectivity between SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Advanced Event Mesh (steps 1 and 2). For a live step-by-step demonstration of the setup, please review this video: üëâ SAP Tech Bytes: Configuring SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh

Configuring Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core

Orchestration in SAP AI Core is a managed service that enables unified access, control, and execution of generative AI models through standardized APIs, templating, and configurable AI workflow components.

In our scenario, we will utilize it to chain together prebuilt steps, such as data masking and foundation model invocation, to generate a personalized email body in HTML format via a single API call.

To access the Orchestration service in SAP AI Core, you need to set up Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad. Please refer to either of the following resources for setup instructions:

  • SAP Discovery Mission: Set Up SAP AI Core Generative AI Hub
  • SAP Developer Center Tutorial: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - Setup

Before moving to the next step, please ensure that your orchestration configuration is deployed and is in the RUNNING status.

Building the Orchestration Workflow

In this example, we will build the orchestration workflow for the event of Business Partner change.

Within SAP AI Launchpad, navigate to Generative AI Hub -> Orchestration and click Edit Workflow to select the workflow steps you require.

For our scenario, deselect the Input Translation and Output Translation steps, as they are not needed.

In the Templating step, we define prompts that guide LLM on how to perform its task.

We configure two types of messages for our scenario:

  • System Prompt
  • User Prompt

The system prompt defines the overall behavior, tone, and role of the LLM. It sets global instructions that remain consistent across requests, ensuring predictable formatting and response style.

For our use case, the system prompt will instruct the LLM to act as a multilingual assistant that compares old and new Business Partner profiles and generates a compliant email.

You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".
Instructions:
- Detect all relevant changes (ignore changes in fields named change_time or change_date).
- Summarize the changes clearly and concisely.
- Keep it concise and clear.
- Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
- Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
- Use an unordered list (<ul>) with list items (<li>) to list the changes.
- Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
- End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
- Keep the tone friendly, clear, and professional.
- Do not generate the email subject line, only the body.

The user prompt provides the dynamic, task-specific input for each request. Here, we pass actual data: the old profile payload, new profile payload, and target language. These placeholders will be replaced at runtime to generate personalized content.

Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}
Here is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}
Here is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}

 

In the Data Masking step, we can anonymize or pseudonymize personally identifiable information from the input for selected entities. For our scenario, we will select the Pseudonymization option. This will substitute personally identifiable information in selected categories with a MASKED_ENTITY_ID placeholder and allow us to unmask the LLM response before returning it to the Sender.

The Input Filtering step allows you to apply content safety filters to the incoming data before invoking the foundation model.

In the Model Configuration step, we can select the desired model (e.g., GPT-4.1) and configure relevant parameters such as temperature, token limits, etc.

Finally, the Output Filtering step enables content safety filtering on the LLM-generated response to ensure compliance and prevent undesired content.

Once the orchestration workflow is configured, you can inspect its JSON definition and download it locally. This definition will be used later when invoking the orchestration workflow via API from Cloud Integration.

Additionally, you can test the orchestration inference directly within SAP AI Launchpad by providing sample input variables. The testing tool allows you to view and trace the LLM response and fine-tune the workflow configuration as needed.

When inspecting the output payload, you can clearly trace the results of each orchestration step ‚Äì such as Input Masking, Output Unmasking, Input Filtering, and Output Filtering.

To learn more about Orchestration in SAP AI Core, refer to the SAP Developer Center Tutorials: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - orchestration.

Configure SAP Cloud Integration Business Partner Notification iFlow

Now that we have our SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, and the Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core configured, we can proceed with the Cloud Integration iFlow configuration.

This iFlow ensures that Business Partner changes trigger compliant AI-generated email notifications, while maintaining data consistency in HANA Cloud. It leverages SAP Advanced Event Mesh, CAP, and Generative AI Hub for an automated end-to-end process.

High-Level iFlow Overview

  • Triggered by AEM Queue when a new event is published.
  • Retrieves BP details from S/4HANA Cloud.
  • (If event is BP update) Fetches old BP payload from HANA Cloud (via CAP service).
  • Invokes the Orchestration Workflow API to compare old vs. new payloads and generate an HTML email content while ensuring that no sensitive information is passed to LLM.
  • Upserts updated BP details into SAP HANA Cloud via CAP service.
  • Sends an email to the Business Partner.

Step-by-Step Process Breakdown

  1. Event Trigger
    • The iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and processes incoming events.
  2. Retrieve Business Partner Details
    • An OData request is sent to SAP S/4HANA Cloud to fetch the latest BP details.
    • Key parameters (e.g., BP ID, BP email) are extracted and saved into the properties for further processing.
  3. Map to CAP Format
    • BP details are transformed into the CAP service data model.
    • The new payload is stored in XML and JSON format for further use.
  4. Conditional Logic
    • BP creation ‚Üí No old payload is retrieved.
    • BP update ‚Üí Old payload is retrieved for comparison.
  5. Retrieve Old Payload from HANA Cloud (BP update only)
    • The iFlow calls the CAP service to fetch the previous BP record. Please refer to the GitHub repository businesspartner_srv for more information on the CAP service. In our scenario, the CAP service acts as an intermediary that retrieves old Business Partner data from SAP HANA Cloud, provides an OData service for data access, and enables the upsert of updated details.
  6. AI-Based Email Generation
    • A subprocess calls the Orchestration Workflow API via the AI adapter to create a personalized HTML email body in a GDPR-compliant way.
  7. Upsert BP Details in HANA Cloud
    • The updated BP details are upserted into SAP HANA Cloud via the CAP service.
  8. Send Email
    • The iFlow sends an email using the Mail Adapter.

You can find this iFlow as a ZIP archive here: AEM_GenAI_BPMailGenerator_blog.zip

For this blog, we‚Äôll take a closer look at Step #6, where the AI Receiver Adapter is used to invoke the Orchestration Workflow API configured in the previous section.

1) In our case, the easiest way to prepare a payload for the AI Receiver Adapter is by using a small Groovy script.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonOutput

Message processData(Message message) {
    def map = message.getProperties()

    def createBP = map.get("EventType").toString() == "sap.s4.beh.businesspartner.v1.BusinessPartner.Created.v1" ? true : false

    // Dynamic user template
    def userText = createBP
        ? "Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}\nHere is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}"
        : "Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}\nHere is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}\nHere is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}"

    def userTemplate = [
        role: "user",
        content: [
            [
                type : "text",
                text : userText
            ]
        ]
    ]

    def systemText = createBP
        ? """You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to generate a warm, professional welcome email for a newly created Business Partner profile based on the provided NEW profile payload.

        Instructions:
        - Welcome the Business Partner.
        - Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
        - Mention that their profile has been successfully created.
        - Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
        - Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
        - Keep it concise and clear.
        - Keep the tone friendly, professional, and approachable.
        - End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
        - Do not generate the email subject line, only the body."""
        
        : """You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".

        Instructions:
        - Detect all relevant changes (ignore changes in fields named change_time or change_date).
        - Summarize the changes clearly and concisely.
        - Keep it concise and clear.
        - Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
        - Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
        - Use an unordered list (<ul>) with list items (<li>) to list the changes.
        - Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
        - End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
        - Keep the tone friendly, clear, and professional.
        - Do not generate the email subject line, only the body."""

    def systemTemplate = [
        role: "system",
        content: [
            [
                type : "text",
                text : systemText
            ]
        ]
    ]
    
    def language = map.get("language")
    def newPayload = map.get("new_payload_json")
    
    def inputParams = [
        language_name: language,
        new_payload: newPayload instanceof String ? newPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(newPayload)
    ]
    
    if (!createBP) {
        def oldPayload = map.get("old_payload_json")
        inputParams.old_payload = oldPayload instanceof String ? oldPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(oldPayload)
    }


    // Build the JSON structure
    def payload = [
        orchestration_config: [
            module_configurations: [
                llm_module_config: [
                    model_name: "gpt-4.1",
                    model_params: [
                        frequency_penalty: 0,
                        presence_penalty: 0,
                        max_completion_tokens: 24576,
                        temperature: 1
                    ],
                    model_version: "2025-04-14"
                ],
                templating_module_config: [
                    template: [
                        userTemplate,
                        systemTemplate
                    ],
                    defaults: [:]
                ],
                filtering_module_config: [
                    input : [
                        filters: [
                            [
                                type: "azure_content_safety",
                                config: [
                                    Hate: 2,
                                    SelfHarm: 2,
                                    Sexual: 2,
                                    Violence: 2,
                                    PromptShield: true
                                ]
                            ]
                        ]
                    ],
                    output: [
                        filters: [
                            [
                                type  : "azure_content_safety",
                                config: [
                                    Hate: 2,
                                    SelfHarm: 2,
                                    Sexual: 2,
                                    Violence: 2
                                ]
                            ]
                        ]
                    ]
                ],
                masking_module_config: [
                    masking_providers: [
                        [
                            type: "sap_data_privacy_integration",
                            method: "pseudonymization",
                            entities: [
                                [type: "profile-credit-card-number"],
                                [type: "profile-driverlicense"],
                                [type: "profile-email"],
                                [type: "profile-sensitive-data"],
                                [type: "profile-ethnicity"],
                                [type: "profile-gender"],
                                [type: "profile-pronouns-gender"],
                                [type: "profile-iban"],
                                [type: "profile-location"],
                                [type: "profile-nationalid"],
                                [type: "profile-nationality"],
                                [type: "profile-org"],
                                [type: "profile-passport"],
                                [type: "profile-person"],
                                [type: "profile-phone"],
                                [type: "profile-political-group"],
                                [type: "profile-sapids-public"],
                                [type: "profile-religious-group"],
                                [type: "profile-sapids-internal"],
                                [type: "profile-ssn"],
                                [type: "profile-sexual-orientation"],
                                [type: "profile-trade-union"],
                                [type: "profile-address"],
                                [type: "profile-url"],
                                [type: "profile-university"],
                                [type: "profile-username-password"]
                            ],
                            mask_grounding_input: [enabled: false],
                            allowlist: []
                        ]
                    ]
                ]
            ]
        ],
        input_params: inputParams
    ]

    // Serialize to JSON string
    def jsonString = JsonOutput.toJson(payload)
    message.setBody(jsonString)

    return message
}

This script constructs the payload expected by the Orchestration API of SAP AI Core.

Note that the settings within the module_configurations block match the configuration that you downloaded from SAP AI Launchpad.

2) To set up a Connection to our AI Core Orchestration deployment, we first need to configure a Security Material.
In your SAP BTP Cockpit and access the service key of the SAP AI Core (extended plan) service instance created earlier.

Create an OAuth2 Client Credentials Security Material with:

  • Token Service URL: url from the service key + ‚Äú/oauth/token‚Äù
  • Client ID: clientid from the service key
  • Client Secret: clientsecret from the service key

On the Connection tab of the AI Receiver Adapter:

  • Set the Address to the AI_API_URL from the service key.
  • Reference the Security Material in the OAuth2 Client Credentials field.

On the Processing tab:

  • Set Request Payload Source to ‚ÄúExchange Body‚Äù.
  • Provide the Orchestration Deployment ID and AI Resource Group from SAP AI Launchpad.

3) JSON output is converted into XML for further processing.

4) Content Modifier step is used to extract the email_body from the Orchestration API response via the XPath expression: /root/orchestration_result/choices/message/content

Testing the Scenario End-to-End

With all components configured, it‚Äôs time to put the setup to the test.

üìΩÔ∏è Watch Event-Driven Business Partner Email Notification Demo 

The video walks through the entire process ‚Äì showing the change in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the processing inside Cloud Integration, and the final email received by the Business Partner.

Conclusion

This scenario highlights how simple and seamless it is to invoke SAP AI Core from Cloud Integration to generate compliant, human-sounding content.

With just a small Groovy script to prepare the payload, CPI can call an SAP AI Core Orchestration Workflow directly via the AI Receiver Adapter ‚Äì without complex custom coding or middleware. All compliance safeguards, such as data masking and filtering, are handled by the orchestration workflow, ensuring that no sensitive information is ever sent to the LLM.

The result is an automated, end-to-end process where a Business Partner update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud triggers an event, CPI processes it, SAP AI Core generates the compliant email body, and the recipient is informed ‚Äì all with minimal configuration effort.

This pattern can be applied to other master data objects and backend systems, as well as to any scenario where Cloud Integration must securely generate AI-based content ‚Äî making it a powerful blueprint for scaling compliant AI adoption across the enterprise.

sap.ui.define([

      oCityModel.loadData("model/cityData.json");
      this.getView().setModel(oCityModel);

      oCityModel.attachRequestCompleted(() => {
        const aCities = oCityModel.getData();
        if (aCities?.length > 0) {
          const firstCity = aCities[0];
          this.loadCurrentWeather(firstCity.lat, firstCity.lon);
        }
      });
    },

    onCityChange: function (oEvent) {
      const sKey = oEvent.getParameter("selectedItem").getKey();
      const [lat, lon] = sKey.split(",");
      this.loadCurrentWeather(lat, lon);
    },

    loadCurrentWeather: async function (lat, lon) {
      const apiKey = "e21c9996e2801f22e2bd0f7d11d1b367";
      const url = `https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?lat=${lat}&lon=${lon}&appid=${apiKey}&lang=tr`;

      try {
        const response = await fetch(url);
        const data = await response.json();

        const row = {

          temp: data.main.temp,
          feels_like: data.main.feels_like,
          humidity: data.main.humidity,
          wind_speed: data.wind.speed,
          weather_desc: data.weather?.[0]?.description || ""
        };

        const oWeatherModel = new JSONModel({ Forecast: [row] });
        this.getView().setModel(oWeatherModel, "weatherModel");
      } catch (err) {
        console.error("Anlƒ±k hava durumu alƒ±namadƒ±:", err);
      }
    }
  });
});

      return isNaN(k) ? "N/A" : (k - 273.15).toFixed(1);
    }
  };
});

entry.title: Bridging EDI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Seamless EDI-to-SOAP Integration
entry.content:
In the fast-paced world of business today, it's crucial to connect traditional EDI systems with modern cloud ERP systems for streamlined operations. This blog takes a closer look at an integration fllow that handles inbound EDI messages, transforms them into SOAP format and facilitate effortless communication with SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Let's explore how this approach changes data formats and guarantees a reliable,standards-complaint integration between legacy and cloud systems.

Note:  For detailed steps on creating and exporting the required MIG and MAG files used in this integration, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

Step-by-Step Guide: EDI to SOAP Inbound Integration Flow

Here‚Äôs a detailed look at the entire integration flow (iFlow) for processing EDI to SOAP inbound messages. This iFlow covers all the essential steps and components needed to receive, validate, transform, and route EDI messages into SOAP format, ensuring a smooth connection to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.

Step 1: Receive EDI Data via AS2

To initiate the integration, configure the AS2 adapter to receive inbound EDI messages. This configuration supports secure and reliable data transfer in B2B scenarios involving EDI communication.

Note: For detailed steps on setting up the AS2 adapter, refer to the blog: Step-by-Step Guide: Secure File Exchange with AS2 Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration ‚Äì SAP Community

Step 2: Add Start Message

Add a Start Message event to initiate the integration flow when EDI data is received through AS2.

Step 3: Add EDI Splitter

Add an EDI Splitter for handling incoming EDI messages. It breaks them down into individual transactions, checks their structure for validity, and can also generate acknowledgments if necessary.

Important:All the XSD and mapping files mentioned in this flow( ASC-X12 XSD, preproc.xsl, and others)‚Äîare created and exported during the MIG and MAG setup process in SAP Integration Advisor.
For a step-by-step guide on generating and exporting these files, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File
  1. To upload ASC-X12 XSD file, navigate to the X12 tab in the EDI Splitter configuration. You‚Äôll find the file in the Source folder that was extracted during the MAG export.
  2. This file outlines the structure of the incoming EDI message, allowing the splitter to accurately parse and process the X12 message.

Step 4: Add Router

Now, let‚Äôs add a Router following the EDI Splitter. This step is crucial for separating EDI messages from acknowledgement messages, especially if you‚Äôve enabled the generation of acknowledgements in the splitter.

Let's define two routing paths:

1. Acknowledgement Route: This route deals with acknowledgement messages independently.

In the Processing tab, you‚Äôll see:

Expression Type Options:

  • XML: This is used when the message is formatted in XML.
  • NON_XML: This is for messages that aren‚Äôt in XML format, where routing is based on the message headers.

We opt for NON_XML since the acknowledgement message isn‚Äôt in XML, so the router checks the message headers instead of the XML content.

 Condition: ${header.EDI_ACKNOWLEDGEMENT} = 'true'

 

2. Default Route: Responsible for processing standard EDI messages.

No condition needed (processes all other messages)

Step 5: Integrate EDI to XML Converter

Now, let‚Äôs add an EDI to XML Converter to convert the EDI message into XML format.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File

  1. Navigate to the X12 tab and upload the ASC-X12.xsd file from the Source folder that you got from the MAG export.
  2. The ASC-X12 XSD file defines the structure of the incoming EDI message, enabling the EDI to XML Converter to accurately interpret and transform the EDI data into XML format.

Step 6: Include XSLT Mapping (Pre-processing)

Next up, we‚Äôll add XSLT Mapping to handle data preprocessing and transformation.

  • Upload preproc.xsl File
  1. Under the Processing tab, upload the preproc.xsl File from the Source folder extracted from the MAG export.
  2.  This step modifies the XML structure created from the EDI message, ensuring it aligns with the expected input format for message mapping.

Step 7: Add XML Validator (Post-processing)

Add an XML Validator to validate the pre-processed XML.

  • Upload X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd File
  1. Navigate to the Validation tab and upload the X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd file from the Source folder you extracted from the MAG export.
  2. This step makes sure that the transformed XML adheres to the expected schema before you proceed to message mapping, helping you identify any structural issues early on.

Step 8: Implement XSLT Mapping (Main Mapping)

Let‚Äôs add an XSLT Mapping to transform the validated EDI XML into the target SOAP message structure.

  • Upload Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl File

  1. Under the Processing tab, you‚Äôll need to upload the Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl file from the root folder of the exported MAG zip file.
  2. This main mapping file, which was generated by SAP Integration Advisor (IA), is crucial for transforming the data into the right format for SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Step 9: Apply XSLT Mapping (Post-processing)

Add an XSLT Mapping to adjust the mapped XML output to the final structure required by the target system.

  • Upload SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl File
  1. Head over to the Processing tab and upload the SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl file from the Target MIG folder.
  2. This ensures the transformed XML matches the exact format expected by the target system for successful processing.

Step 10: Add SOAP Receiver Adapter

Use the SOAP Receiver Adapter to connect to SAP S/4HANA and transmit the transformed XML payload over a SOAP-based web service. This adapter ensures that the data is encapsulated in a SOAP envelope and sent to the appropriate endpoint.

  • Address:Enter the SOAP service endpoint URL provided by your target system.

  • URL to WSDL:Click on Browse and upload the .wsdl file that corresponds to your target SOAP service. CPI will automatically fill in the Service, Endpoint, and Operation Name fields based on the WSDL information.
  • Authentication: Basic
  • Credential Name: Enter the Credential Name of the User Credentials you set up in Security Material.

This marks the end of the configuration for the EDI-to-SOAP inbound integration flow. With this iFlow in action, incoming EDI messages are handled efficiently and routed to the S/4HANA target system in the required SOAP format.
